Description: Red pottery ostracon, currently in two sections, although comprising six fragments, from the shoulder section of a large vessel, probably an amphora, with traces of one line of thick black-painted demotic text on the exterior, another one above, shorter, slightly oblique, and partly faded. A group of two other signs, maybe Greek, is painted above them, on the right side, and traces of another inscription on the left side.
Curator's comments: One of "about a dozen fragments of demotic inscriptions on pieces of jars and cups" mentioned by W.M.F. Petrie, Tanis ii, Nebesheh and Defenneh, p. 74 § 71.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1888 / Tanis. Part II. Nebesheh (Am) and Defenneh (Tahpanhes) (p. 74 § 71)
Trismegistos / An interdisciplinary portal of papyrological and epigraphic resources (389626) (http://www.trismegistos.org/text/389626)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.40, p.117, p.228, pl.70)
Condition: fair (restored from fragments and text faded)
